qas.question: What is one example of an acoustic phonograph on which one would listen to electric recordings?
What allowed better sounds inside the cabinet of the orthoponic phonograph?

answers.text: folded horn with an exponential taper

qas.question: What adjustments were made to the orthophonic  to accommodate electric recordings?

answers.text: mechanical pickup head was redesigned with lower resonance than the traditional mica type

qas.question: Was it common to hear electric recordings on phonographs?
How similar was the sound of a orthodontic  record to a radio?

context: It was <a3_0>not unusual<a3_0/> for electric recordings to be played back on acoustic phonographs. The <a0_0>Victor Orthophonic phonograph<a0_0/> was a prime example where such playback was expected. In the Orthophonic, which benefited from telephone research, the <a2_0>mechanical pickup head was redesigned with lower resonance than the traditional mica type<a2_0/>. Also, a <a1_0>folded horn with an exponential taper<a1_0/> was constructed inside the cabinet to provide better impedance matching to the air. As a result, playback of an Orthophonic record <a4_0>sounded like<a4_0/> it was coming from a radio.
